advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tony Mattson for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #17</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Christian Hart for this scan</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (DEC. 1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE BACK</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Oric opens a full world to you"<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JULY 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote>DEC Advertises its range of networking products.<p class="petitgris">Byte magazine</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #5 </strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT (OCTOBER 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Goupil plays on all tables"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>found on the system box</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert introduced three new Digital professional computers: the <b>Professional 300 Series</b>, the <b>DECmate II</b>, and the <b>Rainbow 100</b> <br><br> Advert said: <br><br> <font color="#666666">All that personal computers needed were a few professional standards. <br><br> Until now, manufacturer have made personal computers that were a hopeful compromise between home and use business. But now, Digital Equipment Corporation offers the first personal computers designed and built strictly for professional use. And since different professionals have different needs, Digital is introducing not one, but three personal computers made to professional standards.</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LISA ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>He is rich (enough to buy a LISA !), he is relaxed... He is the typical advertising executive of the 80's.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROTOTYPE SOFTWARE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This picture from an early advert published in january 1983 is very interesting (the TO-7 was just released then). The text below it said "Hours of entertainment...". But when you look more carefully at the software boxes you realise that they are fake! Only the two extreme boxes are real, but still shows the same game title "3-D TIC-TAC TOE"! So there is only one game presented here! The photograph was surely taken at an early development stage... <br><br> Even the name of the computer written on top of the boxes: "TOM 7" (Tele Ordinateur Multimedia?) seems to be an early name for the TO-7... <br><br> Hours of entertainment they said...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 8-PAGE US ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAGAZINE COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote>The TO-7/70 made the cover of french magazine Micro7 on february 1985.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AUSTRALIAN ADVERT (1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to John Kahler for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PASOPIA 16 JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris"><a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/">http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/</a></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (APR. 87) </strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> VICTOR AD #4 (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #6 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The new sale price is $99.95 instead of 149.95 <br><br> Advert said: <br><br> <font color="#666666">The ZX81 represents the latest technology in microelectronics. More than 10,000 are sold every week. In fact, the ZX81 is the best selling personal computer in the world.</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JUNE 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It's new. It's the Hit-Bit" <br><br> "The computer according to Sony"</blockquote>

computer.builtInGames: 7 games pinball and breakout games (pinball I, pinpaddle I, pinball II, pinpaddle II, Basketball, Breakout, Breakaway)
computer.description:
In 1977, a new type of ball and paddle system was launched: Video Pinball. This game also existed in the arcade under the same name, hence the home versions sold by Atari (Video Pinball, model C-380) and Sears (Pinball Breakaway, model 99713), pictured here. There even was a japanese version, the Epoch TV Block.
See Atari Video Pinball, model C-380 entry for more info. The only differences are the labels, including game names...
computer.keyboard: 1 big paddle built-in the case + 2 side buttons for pinball games
computer.language: 7 games pinball and breakout games (pinball I, pinpaddle I, pinball II, pinpaddle II, Basketball, Breakout, Breakaway)
computer.name: Tele-Games Pinball Breakaway (model 99713)
computer.ports: Video output TV RF through switch box, power in
computer.power: 6 x C battery cells or external power supply (9v DC, 500 mA)
